issue.title: chore: update bazel to 6.4.0
issue.body: Trying to get more info on the Lombok stamping issue on Windows CI. See also https://github.com/bazelbuild/bazel/issues/10363 and https://github.com/bazelbuild/bazel/pull/18185

comment.body:
A bit more detailed error message with Bazel 6.4.0:
```
(21:31:13) ERROR: C:/b/r7qfoniz/external/maven/BUILD:2647:11: Stamping the manifest of @maven//:org_projectlombok_lombok [for tool] failed: failed to delete output files before executing action: C:/b/r7qfoniz/execroot/build_buildfarm/bazel-out/x64_windows-opt-exec-2B5CBBC6/bin/external/maven/v1/https/repo1.maven.org/maven2/org/projectlombok/lombok/1.18.24/processed_lombok-1.18.24.jar (Permission denied)
```

But no hints on how to fix it :(
I'm bumping Lombok in https://github.com/bazelbuild/bazel-buildfarm/pull/1434/commits/38213406f5c444f87e6553ae77780d68e86ef96e, we could move that commit to this PR if desired.

issue.title: Configurable bucket for histogram metrics
issue.body:
All buildfarm histogram metrics except grpclatency is not configurable, and some of them have improper default value, especially time related metrics on large repo (`execution_time_ms,input_fetch_time_ms,queue_time_ms...`) with too small bucket (the largest is [10ms, +inf]).

Can we make those bucket configurable or set some more proper default vaules? Thanks.

comment.body:
It might be sufficient to update the prometheus client dependency from using `io.prometheus:simpleclient:0.10.0` to `io.prometheus:prometheus-metrics-core:1.0.0` which now supports prometheus native histograms ( see http://prometheus.github.io/client_java/getting-started/metric-types/#histogram ) That does have the caveat that the prometheus server run with `--enable-feature=native-histograms`   -- so there might be value in implementing custom buckets for classic histograms too.

Note upgrading to the 1.0.0 prometheus client would also require updating/patching `me.dinowernli:java-grpc-prometheus` as it uses simpleclient as well to register its metrics if grpc metrics are enabled -- it would at least need to rebuild with the new compatability layer.

commits.message:
Support OutputPaths in OutputDirectory

Specifying any number of OutputPaths will ignore OutputFiles (consistent
with uploads). Where an OutputPath specifies an output directory, the
action must be able to create the directory itself.

pull_request.title: Support OutputPaths in OutputDirectory

issue.title: when blob file miss，rbe client is stuck
issue.body:
buildfarm version: 2.4.0
android rbe: 0.57.0.4865132
buildfarm configuration: 
- server: 3 k8s pods
- shard workers: more than 10 k8s pods, and execute workers act as CAS workers

A pod in the workers is faulty，so i have to delete the pod and re-create it with empty cache dir. But `ContentAddressableStorage:` and `ActionCache:` data in redis aren't delete. Then when android rbe client is stuck when it use buildfarm server to remote build, and client error log is:
```
cas.go:1399] Error downloading {blob file hash}/{blob file size}: rpc error: code = NotFound desc = No workers found.
cas.go:1408] Internal tool error - matching map entry
```

I found that remote-api only considers the possible `NOT_FOUND` status returned by the GetActionResult, GetTree, and WaitExecution interfaces, but doesn't consider  the `NOT_FOUND` status of the download interface.
> Question 1: maybe server must ensure that the result of `GetActionResult`  is consistent with the result of download?

And then I set `ensureOutputsPresent: true` to test(deleting blob files separately)，but the first build is still stuck after delete blob file，and the result of `GetActionResult` is still 200. And the second build is success，and the result of `GetActionResult` is `NotFound`.  
Question 2: why the first build is still stuck when set `ensureOutputsPresent: true`? 

Question 3: I think can the CAS data stored by workers be stored in the Redis，similar to a bidirectional linked list, use the worker address as the key, the value is a cas list？

comment.body: I'm not sure what the state of that PR is. @luxe may be able to provide some more detail on if it would make sense to re-visit it. @shirchen do you have that change deployed in your cluster?

issue.title: when blob file miss，rbe client is stuck
issue.body:
buildfarm version: 2.4.0
android rbe: 0.57.0.4865132
buildfarm configuration: 
- server: 3 k8s pods
- shard workers: more than 10 k8s pods, and execute workers act as CAS workers

A pod in the workers is faulty，so i have to delete the pod and re-create it with empty cache dir. But `ContentAddressableStorage:` and `ActionCache:` data in redis aren't delete. Then when android rbe client is stuck when it use buildfarm server to remote build, and client error log is:
```
cas.go:1399] Error downloading {blob file hash}/{blob file size}: rpc error: code = NotFound desc = No workers found.
cas.go:1408] Internal tool error - matching map entry
```

I found that remote-api only considers the possible `NOT_FOUND` status returned by the GetActionResult, GetTree, and WaitExecution interfaces, but doesn't consider  the `NOT_FOUND` status of the download interface.
> Question 1: maybe server must ensure that the result of `GetActionResult`  is consistent with the result of download?

And then I set `ensureOutputsPresent: true` to test(deleting blob files separately)，but the first build is still stuck after delete blob file，and the result of `GetActionResult` is still 200. And the second build is success，and the result of `GetActionResult` is `NotFound`.  
Question 2: why the first build is still stuck when set `ensureOutputsPresent: true`? 

Question 3: I think can the CAS data stored by workers be stored in the Redis，similar to a bidirectional linked list, use the worker address as the key, the value is a cas list？

comment.body: Yes I use cas+execute workers. I see this problem when my workers scale down. We use bazel 5.3.1. To work around it you can enable graceful shutdown, which is available in v2.6.1. This config will wait x seconds for any executions in progress to finish before shutting down the worker. Obviously not going to help if your worker is already broken but it will solve the issue in case of normal shutdown. https://github.com/bazelbuild/bazel-buildfarm/blob/main/examples/config.yml#L128.

comment.body:
Hi, @80degreeswest
I noticed that https://github.com/bazelbuild/bazel-buildfarm/pull/976 could solve my problem, but not merge.
I tested the efficiency of adding check disk storage before and after. It doesn't seem to add much time at the moment.

issue.title: Latest worker image fails on startup due to classfile version mismatch
issue.body:
I'm on an M1 Mac running macOS Sonoma and Docker Desktop 4.24.2.

When running `examples/bf-run start`, the worker container stops immediately. Looking at the logs, the output is:
```
Error: LinkageError occurred while loading main class build.buildfarm.worker.shard.Worker
	java.lang.UnsupportedClassVersionError: build/buildfarm/worker/shard/Worker has been compiled by a more recent version of the Java Runtime (class file version 61.0), this version of the Java Runtime only recognizes class file versions up to 55.0
```

If the tag `latest` is replaced with `v2.6.1` the problem goes away. I couldn't find a place in the code where the container is pushed, so I suspect this is done externally (but happy to stand corrected if I missed something).

I suspect the cause is that the process that builds the code that goes in the container has a locally installed Java 17 toolchain, which is picked up by Bazel. If that's the case, the solution should be to make the Java build hermetic with the following:

```diff
diff --git a/.bazelrc b/.bazelrc
index adbb3c68..79b97837 100644
--- a/.bazelrc
+++ b/.bazelrc
@@ -1,3 +1,9 @@
+build --java_language_version=11
+build --java_runtime_version=remotejdk_11
+
+build --tool_java_language_version=11
+build --tool_java_runtime_version=remotejdk_11
+
 common --enable_platform_specific_config
 
 build:fuse --define=fuse=true
```

Another possibility I considered would be to update the base images to use Java 17, which seem to be already available:

```diff
diff --git a/BUILD b/BUILD
index f552ea9d..688dd0f4 100644
--- a/BUILD
+++ b/BUILD
@@ -148,14 +148,14 @@ oss_audit(
 # Download cgroup-tools so that the worker is able to restrict actions via control groups.
 download_pkgs(
     name = "worker_pkgs",
-    image_tar = "@ubuntu-jammy//image",
+    image_tar = "@ubuntu-mantic//image",
     packages = ["cgroup-tools"],
     tags = ["container"],
 )

 install_pkgs(
     name = "worker_pkgs_image",
-    image_tar = "@ubuntu-jammy//image",
+    image_tar = "@ubuntu-mantic//image",
     installables_tar = ":worker_pkgs.tar",
     installation_cleanup_commands = "rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/*",
     output_image_name = "worker_pkgs_image",
diff --git a/images.bzl b/images.bzl
index 9ab0a8b0..c6c76739 100644
--- a/images.bzl
+++ b/images.bzl
@@ -27,19 +27,11 @@ def buildfarm_images():
     )

     container_pull(
-        name = "ubuntu-bionic",
-        digest = "sha256:4bc527c7a288da405f2041928c63d0a6479a120ad63461c2f124c944def54be2",
+        name = "ubuntu-mantic",
+        digest = "sha256:1419bba15470a95242e917b3abcd8981ae36707b99df5ac705e1eee4d920c51c",
         registry = "index.docker.io",
         repository = "bazelbuild/buildfarm-worker-base",
-        tag = "bionic-java11-gcc",
-    )
-
-    container_pull(
-        name = "ubuntu-jammy",
-        digest = "sha256:da847ee259ebe7f00631a2f0146d9add60ff0f94b031a2e522ce94c78b1335c2",
-        registry = "index.docker.io",
-        repository = "bazelbuild/buildfarm-worker-base",
-        tag = "jammy-java11-gcc",
+        tag = "mantic-java17-gcc",
     )

     container_pull(
```

Still, even in this case I think it would probably be advisable to pin the Java toolchain to use Java 17.

Happy to hear back from the maintainers and contribute with a PR based on that. 🙂

comment.body: Just tested locally after the new images were pushed, looks like it worked. 🙂

issue.title: expire Operation in backplane
issue.body: I just started using Buildfarm not long ago, and I noticed that when the Buildfarm server puts an Operation into the OperationQueue in the backplane, if there is no suitable worker to match this Operation, the Operation will remain in the backplane indefinitely. Do we have any timeout or expiration parameters to configure this situation? thanks

comment.body: @werkt Thank you for the discussion. Indeed, situations like this misconfiguration should not occur or occur very rarely.However, once it happens, it results in the strange situation which requiring manual intervention from the backplane to resolve the issue. Ideally, I hope to set a timeout for the operations in the OperationQueue, such as OperationQueueTimeout. When scanning the queue, if we find that a task has been stalled for too long, we can terminate that operation and notify the client that the task has timed out. this differs from the actual execution timeout configuration, known as defaultActionTimeout. OperationQueueTimeout represents the maximum timeout for tasks that cannot be consumed, while defaultActionTimeout represents tasks that can be consumed but may time out during execution. However, this is just a possible suggestion. If necessary, I may try to fix this issue locally first. If there are further ideas in the future, we can continue the discussion.

I'm on an M1 Mac running macOS Sonoma and Docker Desktop 4.24.2.

When running `examples/bf-run start`, the worker container stops immediately. Looking at the logs, the output is:
```
Error: LinkageError occurred while loading main class build.buildfarm.worker.shard.Worker

```

I suspect the cause is that the process that builds the code that goes in the container has a locally installed Java 17 toolchain, which is picked up by Bazel. If that's the case, the solution should be to make the Java build hermetic with the following:

```diff
--- a/.bazelrc
+++ b/.bazelrc
@@ -1,3 +1,9 @@

+build --tool_java_runtime_version=remotejdk_11

```

Another possibility I considered would be to update the base images to use Java 17, which seem to be already available:

```diff
diff --git a/BUILD b/BUILD
index f552ea9d..688dd0f4 100644
--- a/BUILD
+++ b/BUILD

diff --git a/images.bzl b/images.bzl
index 9ab0a8b0..c6c76739 100644
--- a/images.bzl
+++ b/images.bzl
@@ -27,19 +27,11 @@ def buildfarm_images():
     )

     container_pull(
-        name = "ubuntu-bionic",
-        digest = "sha256:4bc527c7a288da405f2041928c63d0a6479a120ad63461c2f124c944def54be2",
+        name = "ubuntu-mantic",

         registry = "index.docker.io",
         repository = "bazelbuild/buildfarm-worker-base",
-        tag = "bionic-java11-gcc",
-    )
-
-    container_pull(
-        name = "ubuntu-jammy",
-        digest = "sha256:da847ee259ebe7f00631a2f0146d9add60ff0f94b031a2e522ce94c78b1335c2",

-        repository = "bazelbuild/buildfarm-worker-base",
-        tag = "jammy-java11-gcc",
+        tag = "mantic-java17-gcc",

```

Still, even in this case I think it would probably be advisable to pin the Java toolchain to use Java 17.

commits.message:
Pin the Java toolchain to `remotejdk_17` (#1509)

Closes #1508

Cleanups:
- remove the unused `ubuntu-bionic` base image
- replace `ubuntu-jammy:jammy-java11-gcc` with `ubuntu-mantic:mantic-java17-gcc`
- replace `amazoncorretto:19` with `ubuntu-mantic:mantic-java17-gcc`
- swap inverted log file names in a file
